items.message:
River levels are rising rapidly on the Middlesbrough Becks due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middlesbrough Becks, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Storm Antoni is forecast to bring thunderstorms affecting London from midday on Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Waltham Forest, Waltham Abbey, Waltham Cross, Barnet, Nazeing, Enfield, Chingford, Edmonton, Cheshunt or Tottenham areas, there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

This flood alert has been issued due to high spring tides combined with strong winds. 

The first forecast high water is 22:00 on 04/08/23 with a level of 6.46 mAOD and a Force 4 North Westerly wind. 
The second forecast high water is 10:15 on 05/08/23 with a level of 6.31 mAOD and a Force 7 South Westerly wind. 

All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. 

Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at this time, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Due to increasing wind strength, there is a risk of property flooding so Flood Warnings may be issued for tomorrow mornings tide.

Coastal conditions are expected to continue until after the high tides on Saturday 05/08/2023. We will update this message as necessary.

This message will be updated by 15:00 on Saturday, 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.63mAOD at 18:30 on 05/08/23 and 4.67mAOD at 07:00 on 06/08/23.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 35 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 3 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:30 on 06/08/23, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coastal Streams in Redcar and Cleveland
items.message:
River levels are rising rapidly on the Coastal Streams in Redcar and Cleveland due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Coastal Streams in Redcar and Cleveland. We are expecting flooding at East Crescent at Lotus.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 06/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:00 on 05/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 Westerly winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.31 m. The total forecast tide is 5.24 metres Chart Datum (2.50 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour, similar to that seen on Wednesday 02/08/2023. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. After this tide‚ the weather becomes more settled‚ with smaller waves and lighter winds. Sunday's early morning tide is predicted to be 20cm lower and tide levels will fall towards neaps over the coming week. Flood risk will reduce and no further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/08/2023.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 15:15 on 05/08/2023 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with Gale Force 8 Westerly winds and large waves. The weather increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 6.21 metres Chart Datum (3.16 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, minimal flood impacts are expected. A small amount of water could find its way behind the beach and may pond on nearby land and fields including at Climping Street Car Park and Mill Lane. From Sunday 06/08/2023‚ the weather becomes more settled‚ with smaller waves and lighter winds. Sunday's early morning tide is predicted to be 20cm lower and tide levels will fall towards neaps over the coming week. Flood risk will reduce and no further flood impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Shingle and debris can be thrown by large waves. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. Take care if visiting Climping beach. We will update this message by 18:00 on 05/08/2023.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast for the next couple of days is for more unsettled weather which could affect tide heights over the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Tide levels are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and will re-issue a flood alert if necessary.

Water levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast for the next couple of days is for more unsettled weather which could affect tide heights over the weekend. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths may occur between 2:15pm and 4:15pm this afternoon, Saturday 5th August. This is due to an unseasonal low pressure system causing a small tidal surge. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.83mAODN at 3:15pm on Saturday 5th August, which is 0.30m above tide tables, wind force 5, southerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). The following tide at 3:45am may also reach Flood Alert level. You are advised to take care next to the coast as levels are forecast to just reach the Flood Alert threshold. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 5pm today, Saturday 5th August.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding remains possible today, Saturday 05/08/2023. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes. Levels are expected to remain high and may rise further after heavy rainfall this morning. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads which may be flooded. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides.

Areas most at risk include the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.

The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth. The first forecast high water is at 10:30 PM on 04/08/2023 with a level of 7.50 mAODN with westerly force 3 winds. The second forecast high water is at 10:45 AM on 05/08/2023 with a level of 7.37 mAODN with westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

After this tide‚ and the passing of Storm Antoni the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected. We are closing flood gates at Pill and Shirehampton and we will continue to monitor levels closely.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. Incoming high tide levels are now forecast to be below the Flood Alert threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.   
Please avoid contact with flood water.

The high tide has now passed.

No further high tides are expected to reach Flood Alert levels in this cycle.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and issue further alerts if necessary.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
Tide levels are now decreasing. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides and no further impacts are expected. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the sea has now reduced, however, large waves and gale force winds are forecast, so take care near coastal paths and promenades.

items.description: Silk Stream and the Deans, Edgware, Dollis, Mutton and Wealdstone Brooks
items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Storm Antoni is forecast to bring thunderstorms affecting London from midday on Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will see the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Hendon, Wembley, Harrow, Wealdstone, Edgware or Stanmore areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water may also occur.

We expect river levels to rise quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We are continuing to deploy pumps, people and equipment, and liaising with emergency services and local authorities in the Tokyngton area on the Wembley Brook.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

If the heaviest rain affects the Hatch End, Pinner, Ruislip, Ickenham, Hillingdon, or Uxbridge areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Yeading Brooks in London Boroughs of Harrow and Hillingdon

floodArea.riverOrSea: Yeading Brook West, Yeading Brook East

items.message:
We have issued a Flood Alert. Storm Antoni is forecast to bring thunderstorms affecting London from midday on Saturday 5 August. It is currently unclear which areas will experience the heaviest rain.

If the heaviest rain affects the Harrow or Hillingdon areas there is the possibility that rivers could overtop their banks. Flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside gardens is possible from midday on Saturday. Flooding from surface water could also occur.

We expect river levels to respond by rising quickly in areas receiving the heaviest rain. We recommend you stay aware of local weather conditions and water levels. Consider putting your flood plan into action.

We expect the band of rain to leave the area on Saturday evening, scattered showers are forecast for Sunday. We are constantly monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages.

We will update this message on Saturday afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

As a result of spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest tomorrow morning at 10:45 AM on 05/08/2023.

Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Severn Beach including New Passage and Pilning.
The detailed tidal information for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 7.37 mAODN, which is 0.30 m above tide tables, with westerly force 7 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level - for more info refer to local tide tables.)

The risk of flooding from Storm Antoni will reduce after this high tide. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 05/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels remain high on the Lower River Derwent due to rainfall during the week. Flooding remains possible today, Saturday 05/08/2023. Areas most at risk of flooding include local roads, footpaths and low-lying land around Elvington. Further heavy rainfall this morning may cause levels to rise further and other areas including Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle and Wilberfoss may be at risk over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Level of the Fens in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise in response to the current weather conditions.  Areas most at risk are around Middle Level, including Pondersbridge, Ramsey St Mary's, Benwick and Welney.   Further heavy rainfall is expected over the 12 hours which will keep river levels high and could also lead to some surface water problems. Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, 06/08/23, or if the situation changes.
